audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker introducing himself and the purpose of the video, sounding informative and professional. He describes Oracle Virtual Box, what it does, and the outcomes for the video. He sounds like he is reading from a script as he goes over the requirements. The clip ends abruptly with a short, non-specific sound.

The clip begins with a male speaker introducing a website, "www.virtualbox.org," as a place to download VirtualBox. He mentions site features like screenshots, downloads, and documentation, emphasizing the good information it contains.

The clip starts with a single male speaker calmly explaining how to download VirtualBox, mentioning clicking the download section and choosing the appropriate version for one's machine. He specifies "VirtualBox 4.1.14 for Windows host," noting its compatibility with both x86 and 64-bit Windows operating systems. He instructs to click on a specific option and save the file.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker mentioning putting something on a local disk downloads and creating a separate directory called "VirtualBox". The speaker then states they will open it up and simply download the file. This is followed by the same male speaker stating it will be a very short download, and they mention approximately 10 minutes remaining.

The audio begins with someone speaking in a relatively casual tone, suggesting while waiting for something to download, you can either "take a look at the user manual" or explore the site. They mention they will return after the download and proceed to set up "virtual box and Windows 7."

The clip begins with a male speaker noting the last few seconds of an installation process. He mentions that the virtual box has been downloaded and then instructs to close the folders. He says the next step is to set up the program on a Windows 7 computer. After that, silence is heard.

The speaker explains that once VirtualBox has been downloaded to a Windows 7 machine, the next step is to click on the .exe file and install it. The speaker advises the listener to right-click the start button to open Windows Explorer, then navigate to the location where the VirtualBox download resides. In this case, it's C:\Downloads. The speaker continues by describing how to click the VirtualBox file and then run it after a security warning appears. The speaker is male and speaks in an instructional tone.

The audio opens with a male speaker stating that a security warning will come up multiple times during the install. He guides through the installation process, instructing to click 'next,' pick all items, and take the default location. He then mentions creating a shortcut on the desktop, giving a warning that network interfaces may be going up and down during installation, possibly causing disconnection. The speaker continues with instructions, clicking 'yes,' followed by 'install' to begin the installation. The tone remains instructional throughout. Subsequently, user account control windows pop up repeatedly, prompting clicks of 'yes,' and security warnings appear multiple times, requiring clicks of 'install' each time.
The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that "Oracle VM's installation is complete" in a neutral tone. He then instructs to "click finish". The clip ends with ambient sounds.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker, whose voice is normal in tone, suggesting to "close this window right here" and introduces a virtual box, where the latest edition is installed. The speaker mentions a preference of where the virtual machines are installed, as these are usually in a directory, so if you want everyone to be able to use the virtual machines you have to change the preferences. The male speaker then discusses changing the folder and moves on to talking about the C drive, users, and public. The male speaker suggests making a new folder, called "public VMs for public virtual machines". The speaker suggests taking a look at some other settings, noting if you wish to keep your virtual machines private, and not let anyone else access them, you can. He clicks "OK" and finishes speaking, ending the clip with a simple "thank you".
